work.name: University of Toronto
work.summary: Develop and maintain an open-source R package for grading programming assignments with an existing automatic testing framework `testthat`.
highlights: Develop and maintain an open-source R package solution for grading programming assignments with an existing automatic testing framework, ensuring scalability and reliability for over 1,500 users in the university.
Optimize and refactor the codebase for conciseness and readability, enhancing performance and maintainability.

Implement user-friendly features and automate software documentation to improve transparency, reducing the learning cost for non-technical users from weeks to 2 days, resulting in higher user satisfaction and faster adoption.
Leverage CI/CD practices with version control for continuous and collaborative development with professors.

work.name: University of Toronto
work.position: Business Analyst and Client Support (REDCap & JupyterHub)
work.summary: Support the deployment of AI copilot studio chatbots for the university.
highlights: Manage a survey platform with 2K+ users, perform regular updates and functional tests to ensure smooth operation.
Analyze REDCap/JupyterHub usage data with Tableau, SQL, Python/R, identify key trends and business insights.
Solved over 500 incidents for over 50 departments at UofT by email support, online office hours and workshops.

Designed and implemented a secure and efficient online form with user authentication, automating over 1K REDCap requests every year, resulting in significant time and workload reduction as well as storage space savings.
Recognized with the VPOREP Impact Award for launching a collaborative service successfully.

work.name: University of Toronto
work.summary: TA for an undergraduate R & statistics course (class size: 500) for 5 terms, 1-1 weekly tutorial for more than 120 students as a TA.
highlights: TA for an undergraduate Statistical Reasoning and Data Science course of (class size: 500) for 4 terms.
Led a 1-hour tutorial for 24 students weekly: taught R and statistical modeling; evaluated students' assignments.
Hosted office hours (2 hours/week) and monitored online discussion forum for all students on a weekly basis.
Students who participated consistently in my tutorial received A or above and entered the program of study.

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
